DOC.HEAD: Indicted Panamanian Officer Brought to Miami to Face Charges
Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs bgng, `A federal,' with 1 graf to UPDATE with del Cid at Metro Correctional Institute at Miami, more detail on arraignment
DOC.TEXT: A Panamanian officer indicted along with deposed dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega on drug-related charges was escorted to Miami on Monday by U.S. drug enforcement agents, the Justice Department announced. Lt. Col. Luis del Cid, a Noriega loyalist who commanded a Panama Defense Forces unit in the province of Chiriqui, gave himself up to U.S. forces in Panama, said spokeswoman Deborah Burstion-Wade. Del Cid was one of 15 Noriega associates indicted in February 1988 by a federal grand jury in Miami. He is wanted on four counts related to cocaine possession and laundering drug profits, the spokeswoman said. After turning himself in, del Cid was arrested by agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Panama, she said. DEA agents escorted him to Miami. ``Normally he would have been flown in by U.S. marshals, but this was not an ordinary case,'' she said. Ms. Burstion-Wade said Monday night that del Cid had been taken to the Metro Correctional Institute, a federal facility in Miami. His initial court appearance was scheduled for Tuesday afternoon, and U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtenin is to handle the matter for the government, she said. Del Cid surrendered on Saturday and declared loyalty to the new government of Guillermo Endara, installed as president last week after U.S. troops invaded Panama to remove Noriega from power. The Miami indictment unsealed Feb. 5, 1988 against Noriega, del Cid and others alleges that the ousted strongman accepted a $4.6 million bribe from Colombia's Medellin cartel to protect shipments of cocaine, launder money, supply drug laboratories and shield drug traffickers from the law. A separate federal grand jury in Tampa, Fla., indicted Noriega several days later on charges of taking another $5.4 million bribe from the Colombia drug cartel. The Justice Department has said that if Noriega is brought to the United States, he would be tried first in Miami because the prosecutors' case there was stronger than in Tampa.
